request_headers.Accept: Media type(s) that are acceptable for the response
request_headers.Accept-Language: List of acceptable human languages for response
request_headers.Accept-Post: Specifies which media types are accepted for POST requests
request_headers.Access-Control-Request-Headers: Initiates a request for cross-origin resource sharing
request_headers.Access-Control-Request-Method: Initiates a request for cross-origin resource sharing
request_headers.Alt-Used: Identifies the alternative service in use, similar to Host header
request_headers.Attribution-Reporting-Eligible: Indicates response is eligible to register an attribution source or trigger (Experimental)
request_headers.Available-Dictionary: Specifies the best matching dictionary for Compression Dictionary Transport (Experimental)
request_headers.Cache-Control: Used to specify directives for caching mechanisms
request_headers.Connection: Control options for the current connection
request_headers.Content-Digest: Provides a digest of message content for integrity validation
request_headers.Content-DPR: Indicates the device pixel ratio of the client (Non-standard, Deprecated)
request_headers.Content-Encoding: The type of encoding used on the data
request_headers.Content-Length: The length of the request body in octets
request_headers.Content-MD5: A Base64-encoded binary MD5 sum of the content
request_headers.Content-Type: The Media type of the body of the request
request_headers.Cookie: Contains HTTP cookies previously sent by the server with Set-Cookie. Used to maintain session state and pass user preferences and/or information between requests.
request_headers.Critical-CH: Identifies accepted client hints that are critical (Experimental)
request_headers.Date: The date and time at which the message was originated
request_headers.Device-Memory: Indicates approximate available RAM on client device in gigabytes
request_headers.Dictionary-ID: References a dictionary for Compression Dictionary Transport (Experimental)
request_headers.Downlink: Indicates approximate bandwidth of client's connection in Mbps (Experimental)
request_headers.DPR: Indicates client device pixel ratio (Non-standard, Deprecated)
request_headers.Early-Data: Indicates request was conveyed in TLS early data (Experimental)
request_headers.Expect: Indicates expectations that need to be met by server
request_headers.Expect-CT: Indicates that the client expects Certificate Transparency (Deprecated)
request_headers.Forwarded: Disclose original information of a client
request_headers.From: The email address of the user making the request
request_headers.Front-End-Https: Non-standard header field used by Microsoft applications and load-balancers
request_headers.Host: The domain name of the server and TCP port number
request_headers.HTTP2-Settings: Parameters that govern the HTTP/2 connection
request_headers.If-Match: Makes a request conditional. Server returns resources only if they match one of the ETag values
request_headers.If-Modified-Since: Makes a request conditional. Server returns 200 with resource only if modified after the specified date
request_headers.If-None-Match: Makes a request conditional. Server returns 200 with resource only if no ETag matches
request_headers.If-Range: Makes a range request conditional. If condition met, returns 206 with partial content
request_headers.If-Unmodified-Since: Makes a request conditional. Server processes request only if resource hasn't been modified since specified date
request_headers.Keep-Alive: Hints how a connection may be used in terms of timeout and maximum requests
request_headers.Max-Forwards: Used with TRACE to limit number of nodes (proxies) request goes through
request_headers.Origin: Indicates the origin (scheme, hostname, port) that caused the request
request_headers.Permissions-Policy: Controls which browser features can be used in document and iframes (Experimental)
request_headers.Prefer: Allows client to request certain behaviors
request_headers.Priority: Indicates client's preference for response priority order
request_headers.Proxy-Authorization: Authorization credentials for connecting to a proxy
request_headers.Range: Request only part of an entity
request_headers.Referer: The address of the previous web page
request_headers.Referrer-Policy: Controls how much referrer information is included with requests
request_headers.RTT: Indicates approximate round trip time on application layer in milliseconds (Experimental)
request_headers.Save-Data: Indicates client's preference for reduced data usage (Experimental)
request_headers.Sec-Browsing-Topics: Sends the selected topics for the current user along with the associated request
request_headers.Sec-CH-Prefers-Color-Scheme: Media feature client hint providing the user's preference for light or dark color themes
request_headers.Sec-CH-Prefers-Reduced-Motion: User agent client hint indicating preference for animations to be displayed with reduced motion
request_headers.Sec-CH-Prefers-Reduced-Transparency: User agent client hint indicating preference for reduced transparency
request_headers.Sec-CH-UA: User agent client hint providing the user-agent's branding and significant version information
request_headers.Sec-CH-UA-Arch: User agent client hint containing the user-agent's underlying CPU architecture
request_headers.Sec-CH-UA-Bitness: User agent client hint providing the 'bitness' of the user-agent's underlying CPU architecture
request_headers.Sec-CH-UA-Form-Factors: User agent client hint providing information on the user-agent's device form factor
request_headers.Sec-CH-UA-Full-Version: User agent client hint providing the user-agent's full version string (deprecated)
request_headers.Sec-CH-UA-Full-Version-List: User agent client hint providing the user-agent's branding and full version information
request_headers.Sec-CH-UA-Mobile: User agent client hint indicating whether the browser is on a mobile device
request_headers.Sec-CH-UA-Model: User agent client hint indicating the device model on which the browser is running
request_headers.Sec-CH-UA-Platform: User agent client hint providing the platform or operating system on which the user agent is running
request_headers.Sec-CH-UA-Platform-Version: User agent client hint providing the version of the operating system
request_headers.Sec-CH-UA-WoW64: User agent client hint indicating if a 32-bit user-agent application is running on a 64-bit Windows machine
request_headers.Sec-Fetch-Dest: Fetch metadata request header indicating the request's destination
request_headers.Sec-Fetch-Mode: Fetch metadata request header indicating the mode of the request
request_headers.Sec-Fetch-Site: Fetch metadata request header indicating the relationship between request initiator's origin and requested resource
request_headers.Sec-Fetch-User: Fetch metadata request header sent for requests initiated by user activation
request_headers.Sec-GPC: The Sec-GPC (Global Privacy Control) request header indicates whether the user consents to a website or service selling or sharing their personal information
request_headers.Sec-Purpose: Fetch metadata request header indicating the purpose for which the requested resource will be used
request_headers.Sec-WebSocket-Extensions: Used in WebSocket opening handshake to negotiate protocol extensions
request_headers.Sec-WebSocket-Key: Used in WebSocket opening handshake to confirm client's intent to upgrade to WebSocket
request_headers.Sec-WebSocket-Protocol: Used in WebSocket opening handshake to negotiate sub-protocols
request_headers.Sec-WebSocket-Version: Used in WebSocket opening handshake to indicate supported protocol versions
request_headers.TE: The transfer encodings the user agent is willing to accept
request_headers.Trailer: Indicates header fields present in the trailer
request_headers.Transfer-Encoding: The form of encoding used to transfer the entity
request_headers.Upgrade: Ask the server to upgrade to another protocol
request_headers.User-Agent: The user agent string of the user agent
request_headers.Via: Informs the server of proxies through which the request was sent
request_headers.Warning: A general warning about possible problems
request_headers.Width: Device client hint indicating the desired resource width in physical pixels
request_headers.X-Correlation-ID: Correlates HTTP requests between a client and server
request_headers.X-DNS-Prefetch-Control: Controls DNS prefetching, a feature by which browsers proactively perform domain name resolution
request_headers.X-Forwarded-For: Identifies the originating IP address of a client connecting through a proxy server
request_headers.X-Forwarded-Host: Identifies the original host requested by the client
request_headers.X-Forwarded-Proto: Identifies the protocol (HTTP or HTTPS) that a client used to connect to a proxy
request_headers.X-Http-Method-Override: Requests a web application to override the method specified in the request
request_headers.X-Permitted-Cross-Domain-Policies: Defines a meta-policy controlling whether site resources can be accessed cross-origin
request_headers.X-Robots-Tag: Defines how crawlers should index URLs
request_headers.Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: Sends a signal to the server indicating the client's preference for an encrypted and authenticated response, and that the client can successfully handle the upgrade-insecure-requests CSP directive. This header is widely available and supported by modern browsers.

response_headers.Accept-CH: Specifies which client hint headers should be included in subsequent requests. Client hints provide information about the client's device, network, and preferences. Common hints include: Device-Memory (RAM), DPR (device pixel ratio), Viewport-Width, Width, Save-Data (data saving preference), and Sec-CH-UA (user agent information).
response_headers.Accept-Patch: Specifies which patch document formats are supported
response_headers.Accept-Ranges: What partial content range types are supported
response_headers.Access-Control-Allow-Credentials: Indicates whether credentials can be exposed
response_headers.Access-Control-Allow-Headers: Indicates which headers can be used
response_headers.Access-Control-Allow-Origin: Specifies which web sites can participate in CORS
response_headers.Access-Control-Expose-Headers: Indicates which headers can be exposed
response_headers.Access-Control-Max-Age: Indicates how long preflight results can be cached
response_headers.Age: The age the object has been in a proxy cache
response_headers.Allow: Valid methods for a specified resource
response_headers.Attribution-Reporting-Register-Source: Registers a page feature as an attribution source (Experimental)
response_headers.Attribution-Reporting-Register-Trigger: Registers a page feature as an attribution trigger (Experimental)
response_headers.Cache-Control: Tells caching mechanisms whether they may cache
response_headers.Clear-Site-Data: Clears browsing data (cookies, storage, cache) for the requesting website
response_headers.Connection: Control options for the current connection
response_headers.Content-Disposition: An opportunity to raise a 'File Download' dialogue
response_headers.Content-Encoding: The type of encoding used on the data
response_headers.Content-Language: The natural language of the intended audience
response_headers.Content-Length: The length of the response body in octets
response_headers.Content-Location: An alternate location for the returned data
response_headers.Content-MD5: A Base64-encoded binary MD5 sum of the content
response_headers.Content-Range: Where in a full body message this partial message belongs
response_headers.Content-Security-Policy: Controls resources the user agent can load for a page. Directives: default-src (fallback for all fetch directives), script-src (JavaScript sources including eval(), inline scripts, and WebAssembly), style-src (stylesheet sources including inline styles), img-src (image and favicon sources), connect-src (URLs for XMLHttpRequest, WebSocket, and EventSource), font-src (font sources for @font-face), object-src (plugin sources for <object>, <embed>, and <applet>), media-src (media sources for <audio>, <video>, and <track>), frame-src (frame sources for <frame> and <iframe>), child-src (sources for web workers and nested browsing contexts), worker-src (sources for Worker, SharedWorker, and ServiceWorker), manifest-src (sources for application manifest files), base-uri (restricts URLs in <base> elements), form-action (restricts form submission URLs), frame-ancestors (specifies valid parent frames), sandbox (enables sandbox with optional restrictions), report-uri (sends violation reports), report-to (sends violation reports to specified endpoint), upgrade-insecure-requests (upgrades HTTP to HTTPS). Sources can include: 'self' (same origin), 'none' (block all), 'unsafe-inline' (allow inline resources), 'unsafe-eval' (allow dynamic code evaluation), 'wasm-unsafe-eval' (allow WebAssembly), 'strict-dynamic' (trust dynamic scripts), blob: (allow blob URLs), data: (allow data URLs), and specific domains.
response_headers.Content-Security-Policy-Report-Only: Allows web developers to experiment with policies by monitoring their effects
response_headers.Content-Type: The MIME type of this content
response_headers.Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy: Configures the document's policy for loading and embedding cross-origin resources. Requires CORP or CORS headers for cross-site resources, or allows loading with stripped credentials. Applies to loaded resources, iframes, and nested frames.
response_headers.Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy: Controls whether new documents share the same browsing context group (BCG). Options: unsafe-none (default, permits sharing), same-origin (isolates to same-origin only), same-origin-allow-popups (allows popups with unsafe-none), noopener-allow-popups (isolates but allows popups). Prevents XS-Leaks by severing references between documents.
response_headers.Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy: Indicates that the browser should block no-cors cross-origin/cross-site requests to the resource. Specifies which sites/origins are allowed to load the resource.
response_headers.Date: The date and time that the message was sent
response_headers.Delta-Base: Specifies the delta-encoding entity tag of the response
response_headers.ETag: An identifier for a specific version of a resource
response_headers.Expires: Gives the date/time after which the response is considered stale
response_headers.Last-Modified: Contains date/time when resource was last modified
response_headers.Link: Serializes one or more links in HTTP headers
response_headers.Location: Indicates what URL to redirect to
response_headers.No-Vary-Search: Specifies rules for how URL query parameters affect cache matching (Experimental)
response_headers.Observe-Browsing-Topics: Marks topics of interest inferred from calling site's URL (Experimental)
response_headers.Origin-Agent-Cluster: Requests that document be placed in origin-keyed agent cluster
response_headers.P3P: This header is supposed to set P3P policy
response_headers.Pragma: Implementation-specific headers that may have various effects
response_headers.Proxy-Authenticate: Request authentication to access the proxy
response_headers.Public-Key-Pins: HTTP Public Key Pinning, announces hash of website's authentic TLS certificate
response_headers.Refresh: Directs browser to refresh or redirect page after specified time
response_headers.Report-To: Defines named groups of endpoints for warning and error reports (Non-standard, Deprecated)
response_headers.Reporting-Endpoints: Specifies endpoints for sending reports generated by Reporting API
response_headers.Repr-Digest: Provides digest of selected representation of target resource
response_headers.Retry-After: If an entity is temporarily unavailable, this instructs the client to try again
response_headers.Sec-WebSocket-Accept: Used in WebSocket opening handshake to indicate server's willingness to upgrade to WebSocket connection
response_headers.Sec-Speculation-Tags: Contains tag values from speculation rules that resulted in the speculation
response_headers.Server: Describes the software used by the origin server.
response_headers.Server-Timing: Communicates performance metrics about the request-response cycle
response_headers.Service-Worker: Included in fetches for a service worker's script resource
response_headers.Service-Worker-Allowed: Used to broaden the path restriction for a service worker's default scope
response_headers.Service-Worker-Navigation-Preload: Indicates request was from service worker navigation preloading
response_headers.Set-Cookie: Sends a cookie from the server to the user agent. Multiple Set-Cookie headers can be sent in the same response to set multiple cookies. Attributes: Domain (host to send cookie to), Expires (cookie lifetime as HTTP-date), HttpOnly (prevents JavaScript access but can still be accessed by the server), Max-Age (seconds until expiration), Path (URL path requirement), SameSite (controls cross-site sending: Strict/Lax/None), Secure (HTTPS-only transmission).
response_headers.Set-Login: Sent by federated identity provider to set its login status
response_headers.SourceMap: Provides the location of a source map for the resource
response_headers.Speculation-Rules: Provides URLs pointing to text resources containing speculation rule JSON definitions
response_headers.Strict-Transport-Security: A HSTS Policy informing the HTTP client how long to cache the HTTPS only policy
response_headers.Supports-Loading-Mode: Allows a response to opt-in to being loaded in a novel, higher-risk context
response_headers.TE: The transfer encodings the user agent is willing to accept
response_headers.Timing-Allow-Origin: Specifies origins allowed to see values of attributes retrieved via Resource Timing API
response_headers.Tk: Tracking Status header, value suggested to be sent in response to a DNT(do-not-track)
response_headers.Trailer: The Trailer general field value indicates that the given set of header fields is present in the trailer of a message encoded with chunked transfer coding
response_headers.Transfer-Encoding: The form of encoding used to safely transfer the entity to the user
response_headers.Upgrade: Ask the client to upgrade to another protocol
response_headers.Use-As-Dictionary: Lists matching criteria for Compression Dictionary Transport dictionary
response_headers.Vary: Tells downstream proxies how to match future request headers to decide whether the cached response can be used
response_headers.Via: Informs the client of proxies through which the response was sent
response_headers.Viewport-Width: Device client hint providing the client's layout viewport width in CSS pixels
response_headers.Warning: A general warning about possible problems with the entity body
response_headers.Want-Content-Digest: Indicates preference for recipient to send Content-Digest integrity header
response_headers.Want-Repr-Digest: Indicates preference for recipient to send Repr-Digest integrity header
response_headers.WWW-Authenticate: Indicates the authentication scheme that should be used to access the requested entity
response_headers.X-Content-Security-Policy: is an older, experimental HTTP header that served as a precursor to the standard Content-Security-Policy header. Controls resources the user agent can load for a page. Directives: default-src (fallback for all fetch directives), script-src (JavaScript sources including eval(), inline scripts, and WebAssembly), style-src (stylesheet sources including inline styles), img-src (image and favicon sources), connect-src (URLs for XMLHttpRequest, WebSocket, and EventSource), font-src (font sources for @font-face), object-src (plugin sources for <object>, <embed>, and <applet>), media-src (media sources for <audio>, <video>, and <track>), frame-src (frame sources for <frame> and <iframe>), child-src (sources for web workers and nested browsing contexts), worker-src (sources for Worker, SharedWorker, and ServiceWorker), manifest-src (sources for application manifest files), base-uri (restricts URLs in <base> elements), form-action (restricts form submission URLs), frame-ancestors (specifies valid parent frames), sandbox (enables sandbox with optional restrictions), report-uri (sends violation reports), report-to (sends violation reports to specified endpoint), upgrade-insecure-requests (upgrades HTTP to HTTPS). Sources can include: 'self' (same origin), 'none' (block all), 'unsafe-inline' (allow inline resources), 'unsafe-eval' (allow dynamic code evaluation), 'wasm-unsafe-eval' (allow WebAssembly), 'strict-dynamic' (trust dynamic scripts), blob: (allow blob URLs), data: (allow data URLs), and specific domains.
response_headers.X-Content-Type-Options: The only defined value, 'nosniff', prevents Internet Explorer from MIME-sniffing a response away from the declared content-type
response_headers.X-Frame-Options: Controls whether a page can be rendered in a frame, iframe, embed or object. Used to prevent clickjacking attacks.
response_headers.X-Powered-By: Specifies the technology (e.g. ASP.NET, PHP, JBoss) supporting the web application
response_headers.X-UA-Compatible: Recommends the preferred rendering engine to use to display the content
response_headers.X-XSS-Protection: Deprecated header that enabled XSS filtering in older browsers. Options: 0 (disable), 1 (enable), 1;mode=block (block page), 1;report=URI (report violations). Note: This header is deprecated and can create XSS vulnerabilities. Content-Security-Policy is the modern day replacement.
